A lamplighter is a person who used to light and extinguish street lamps before automated systems became common. They played a vital role in providing nighttime illumination in urban areas, using long poles with wicks to ignite and extinguish gas or oil lamps.

Lamplighters served an important service to their communities by illuminating the dark and often dangerous city streets. On the break of dawn, the lamplighter navigates through the labyrinth of urban alleys and avenues, enchanting a warm glow of street lamps against the enfolding darkness.

Today, there's no need for lighting lamps anymore. Lighting systems became more and more automated, making the previous wide-spread profession obsolete.

Arthur Griggs journey has ever been accompanied by the warm glow of street lamps. Stepping into a tradition held up high in his community, he enchants the dark time of day.

Through wind and weather, winter and summer, the commitment to his craft has become more than a profession; it became a proud part of his identity. He brings light, and with it, guidance and safety to his town.

Arthurs service gave him a sense of belonging, looking forward to many more years of service. Faster than expected, technical change disrupted his personal life, leaving a gap behind.

Traditional street lamps work by burning lamp oil or gas. Often ignited with a burning wick attached to long poles, they emerge a radiant light. This classic process has long graced streets with its warm and charming glow.

Modern street lamps are mostly automated and make use of LED lamps. Though efficient, they usually create a strongly artificial light, leaving a less warm and personal charm. With the widespread adaption of more efficient lighting techniques like this, there is just no need for a lamplighter like Arthur anymore.

The lamplighter acts as a metaphor for professions challenged by technical advance. By the example of the lamplighter, this project seeks to portray issues arising when professions, and with it, personal identities, are disrupted.

In the ever faster evolving world we live in, we must find ways to be resilient and adapt, while embracing our unique identities and traditions.

All imagery in this work has been created with Stable Diffusion, a deep learning text-to-image model. This work was developed as part of the course "AI Creative Kitchen" in 2024 under the supervision of Prof. Peter Kabel, HAW Hamburg.
